line.token: * PEAR, the PHP Extension and Application Repository
* Base class for other PEAR classes. Provides rudimentary
* If you want a destructor in your class, inherit PEAR and make a
* destructor method called _yourclassname (same name as the
* constructor, but with a "_" prefix). Also, in your constructor you
* have to call the PEAR constructor: $this->PEAR();.
* The destructor method will be called without parameters. Note that
* at in some SAPI implementations (such as Apache), any output during
* the request shutdown (in which destructors are called) seems to be
* discarded. If you need to get any debug information from your
* destructor, use error_log(), syslog() or something similar.
* IMPORTANT! To use the emulated destructors you need to create the
* Whether to enable internal debug messages.
* Default error mode for this object.
* Default error options used for this object when error mode
* Default error handler (callback) for this object, if error mode is
* Which class to use for error objects.
* List of methods that can be called both statically and non-statically.
* @param string $error_class (optional) which class to use for
* E.g. Archive_Tar calls $this->PEAR() in its constructor.
* @param string $error_class Which class to use for error objects,
* Destructor (the emulated type of...). Does nothing right now,
* but is included for forward compatibility, so subclass
* See the note in the class desciption about output from
* If you have a class that's mostly/entirely static, and you need static
* properties, you can use this method to simulate them. Eg. in your method(s)
* You MUST use a reference, or they will not persist!
* @param string $class The calling classname, to prevent clashes
* @return mixed A reference to the variable. If not set it will be
* Use this function to register a shutdown method for static
* @param mixed $func The function name (or array of class/method) to call
* @param mixed $args The arguments to pass to the function
// if we are called statically, there is a potential
// that no shutdown func is registered. Bug #6445
* Tell whether a value is a PEAR error.
* @param int $code if $data is an error object, return true
* only if $code is a string and
* @return bool true if parameter is an error
* Sets how errors generated by this object should be handled.
* Can be invoked both in objects and statically. If called
* statically, setErrorHandling sets the default behaviour for all
* PEAR objects. If called in an object, setErrorHandling sets
* the default behaviour for that object.
* Object the method was called on (non-static mode)
* When $mode is PEAR_ERROR_TRIGGER, this is the error level (one
* When $mode is PEAR_ERROR_CALLBACK, this parameter is expected
* to be the callback function or method. A callback
* function is a string with the name of the function, a
* callback method is an array of two elements: the element
* at index 0 is the object, and the element at index 1 is
* the name of the method to call in the object.
* When $mode is PEAR_ERROR_PRINT or PEAR_ERROR_DIE, this is
* a printf format string used when printing the error
* This method is used to tell which errors you expect to get.
* Expected errors are always returned with error mode
* PEAR_ERROR_RETURN. Expected error codes are stored in a stack,
* and this method pushes a new element onto it. The list of
* expected errors are in effect until they are popped off the
* Note that this method can not be called statically
* @param mixed $code a single error code or an array of error codes to expect
* @return int the new depth of the "expected errors" stack
* This method pops one element off the expected error codes
* @return array the list of error codes that were popped
* This method checks unsets an error code if available
* @return bool true if the error code was unset, false otherwise
* This method deletes all occurrences of the specified element from
* @param mixed $error_code error code that should be deleted
* @return mixed list of error codes that were deleted or error
// $error_code is a non-empty array here; we walk through it trying
"The expected error you submitted does not exist"
// $error_code comes alone, trying to unset it
"The expected error you submitted does not exist"
"The expected error you submitted is empty"
* This method is a wrapper that returns an instance of the
* configured error class with this object's default error
* handling applied. If the $mode and $options parameters are not
* specified, the object's defaults are used.
* @param mixed $message a text error message or a PEAR error object
* @param int $code a numeric error code (it is up to your class
* to define these if you want to use codes)
* @param mixed $options If $mode is PEAR_ERROR_TRIGGER, this parameter
* specifies the PHP-internal error level (one of
* parameter specifies the callback function or
* method. In other error modes this parameter
* @param string $userinfo If you need to pass along for example debug
* information, this parameter is meant for that.
* @param string $error_class The returned error object will be
* instantiated from this class, if specified.
* @param bool $skipmsg If true, raiseError will only pass error codes,
* the error message parameter will be dropped.
// The error is yet a PEAR error object
// No mode given, try global ones
* Simpler form of raiseError with fewer options. In most cases
* message, code and userinfo are enough.
* @param mixed $message a text error message or a PEAR error object
* @param int $code a numeric error code (it is up to your class
* to define these if you want to use codes)
* @param string $userinfo If you need to pass along for example debug
* information, this parameter is meant for that.
* Push a new error handler on top of the error handler options stack. With this
* you can easily override the actual error handler for some code and restore
* Pop the last error handler used
* OS independent PHP extension load. Remember to take care
* on the correct extension name for case sensitive OSes.
* @return bool Success or not on the dl() call
// if either returns true dl() will produce a FATAL error, stop that
// "If the value is malformed, the build process SHOULD exit with a non-zero error code."

* Standard PEAR error class for PHP 4
* This class is supserseded by {@link PEAR_Exception} in PHP 5
* @param int $mode (optional) error mode, one of: PEAR_ERROR_RETURN,
* @param mixed $options (optional) error level, _OR_ in the case of
* PEAR_ERROR_CALLBACK, the callback function or object/method
"PEAR_ERROR_EXCEPTION is obsolete, use class PEAR_Exception for exceptions"
* Class "Cache_Error" still uses it, among others.
* Get the error mode from an error object.
* Get the callback function/method from an error object.
* @return mixed callback function or object/method array
* Get the error message from an error object.
* Get error code from an error object
* Get the name of this error/exception.
* Get additional debug information supplied by the application.
